rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you. See [[WP:FIXNF]] and [[WP:10CR]]
rev.diff:
Line 33: Line 33:
[[Kirkus reviews]] remarked upon how much Weimar art was political:<ref name="KirkusLaqueurUK">Kirkus UK review of Laqueur, Walter ''Weimar: A cultural history, 1918-1933''</ref> {{cquote|fiercely experimental, iconoclastic and left-leaning, spiritually hostile to big business and bourgeois society and at daggers drawn with Prussian militarism and authoritarianism. Not surprisingly, the old autocratic German establishment saw it as 'decadent art', a view shared by Adolf Hitler who became Chancellor of Germany in January 1933. The public burning of 'unGerman books' by Nazi students on Unter den Linden on 10th May 1933 was but a symbolic confirmation of the catastrophe which befell not only Weimar art under Hitler but the whole tradition of enlightenment liberalism in Germany, a tradition whose origins went back to the 18th century city of Weimar, home to both Goethe and Schiller.}}
[[Kirkus reviews]] remarked upon how much Weimar art was political:<ref name="KirkusLaqueurUK">Kirkus UK review of Laqueur, Walter ''Weimar: A cultural history, 1918-1933''</ref> {{cquote|fiercely experimental, iconoclastic and left-leaning, spiritually hostile to big business and bourgeois society and at daggers drawn with Prussian militarism and authoritarianism. Not surprisingly, the old autocratic German establishment saw it as 'decadent art', a view shared by Adolf Hitler who became Chancellor of Germany in January 1933. The public burning of 'unGerman books' by Nazi students on Unter den Linden on 10th May 1933 was but a symbolic confirmation of the catastrophe which befell not only Weimar art under Hitler but the whole tradition of enlightenment liberalism in Germany, a tradition whose origins went back to the 18th century city of Weimar, home to both Goethe and Schiller.}}
â   â
[[File:Metropolisposter.jpg|thumb|left|120px|Poster of the 1927 movie ''[[Metropolis (film)|Metropolis]]'', by [[Fritz Lang]]]]
 
Weimar culture encompassed the political caricature of [[Otto Dix]] and [[John Heartfield]] and [[George Grosz]], the futuristic skyscraper dystopia of [[Fritz Lang]]'s 1927 film ''[[Metropolis (1927 movie)|Metropolis]]'' and other products of the [[Universum Film AG|UFA]] studio, the beginnings of a new architectural style at the [[Bauhaus]] and the mass housing projects of [[Ernst May]] and [[Bruno Taut]], and the [[decadent]] [[cabaret]] culture of Berlin documented by [[Christopher Isherwood]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} Isherwood's novel ''[[Goodbye to Berlin]]'' has been later transposed to the musical movie ''[[Cabaret (musical)|Cabaret]]''.<ref name="ThompsonB"/>
Weimar culture encompassed the political caricature of [[Otto Dix]] and [[John Heartfield]] and [[George Grosz]], the futuristic skyscraper dystopia of [[Fritz Lang]]'s 1927 film ''[[Metropolis (1927 movie)|Metropolis]]'' and other products of the [[Universum Film AG|UFA]] studio, the beginnings of a new architectural style at the [[Bauhaus]] and the mass housing projects of [[Ernst May]] and [[Bruno Taut]], and the [[decadent]] [[cabaret]] culture of Berlin documented by [[Christopher Isherwood]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} Isherwood's novel ''[[Goodbye to Berlin]]'' has been later transposed to the musical movie ''[[Cabaret (musical)|Cabaret]]''.<ref name="ThompsonB"/>
